description.en: The course will cover different aspects of banking and finance in an international context, including private and public lending, deposit and international transfer of funds and cross-border financial transactions. Students will acquire knowledge of the risks associated with counterparties to transactions and risk mitigation mechanisms. The course will also address regulatory issues (compliance checks) in international transactions.
description.et: Ainekursusel käsitletakse panganduse ja rahanduse erinevaid aspekte rahvusvahelises kontekstis, sealhulgas erasektori ja riigi poolt laenude andmist, hoiustamist ja välisarveldusi ning piirüleseid finantstehinguid. Tudengid omandavad mh teadmisi tehingute osapooltega seotud riskidest ja riskide vähendamise mehhanisme. Ainekursusel käsitletakse ka rahvusvaheliste tehingute regulatiivseid probleeme (vastavuskontroll).

objectives.en: This course will be a survey of the fundamentals of international banking and finance.
objectives.et: Kursus annab ülevaate rahvusvahelise panganduse ja rahanduse põhialustest.

objectives.en: It will include the underlying theories and policies. It will discuss attributes of these types of transactions and provide some of categories of risk and exposure found in these activities, and possible mechanisms to mitigate those risks. Discussions of the problems will be based on some actual examples of international transactions.
objectives.et: Kursus hõlmab rahvusvahelise panganduse ja rahanduse aluseks olevaid teooriaid ja poliitikaid. Kursuse raames käsitletakse eri liiki finantstehingute omadusi, tehingute riskikategooriaid ja -positsioone ning võimalikke mehhanisme nende riskide vähendamiseks. Ainekursus sisaldab ka arutelusid rahvusvaheliste tehingute näitel.

learning_outcomes.en: - gain a fundamental understanding of various types of international transactions, both private and government- sponsored,
learning_outcomes.et: - omandavad põhiteadmised erinevat tüüpi rahvusvahelistest tehingutest, nii era- kui ka valitsuse rahastatud tehingutest

learning_outcomes.en: - understand the reasons customers and financial institutions engage in international finance,
learning_outcomes.et: - mõistavad, miks kliendid ja finantsasutused tegelevad rahvusvahelise finantseerimisega,

learning_outcomes.en: - acquire knowledge about the attributes of types of transactions covered in the course,
learning_outcomes.et: - omandavad teadmisi kursusel käsitletavate tehingutüüpide peamiste omaduste kohta,

learning_outcomes.en: - understand risks involved and regulatory concerns with this category of transactions.
learning_outcomes.et: - mõistavad tehingutega seotud riske ja regulatiivseid probleeme.

notes.et: The course will be taught by Professor David Zarski who has 40 years of experience as an Illinois-licensed attorney and compliance officer in bank and other financial institution regulation and transactions, deposit products, payment systems and GPR cards, consumer credit and mortgage programs, and commercial financing arrangements and lending. He has represented and advised banks, thrifts, state-licensed lenders, debt collectors, fintech companies, and service providers.

description.et: Final assessment will be based on class preparation and participation over the entire course.

description.et:
Lecture 1 

Introduction
Why study this?	
What is a BANK and what function does it serve?
Why are financing arrangements appealing to companies?
International banking	
A bank is divided into two main categories of operations
Deposits and payment functions
Finance and lending
Special aspects and considerations in an international setting

Lecture 2

Deposits and payments
A bank/financial institution does not maintain all deposit at the institution
It only maintains a portion of it deposits in liquid assets, based on its projections of cash needs and regulatory requirements
Taking deposits is a highly regulated activity
As banking has become more international, regulator concerns over "bad actors" using the banking and payments systems for  illegal activities or to hide profits of these activities has put the burden on financial institutions to take steps to identify Anti-Money Laundering (AML)  and Know Your Customer  (KYC) due diligence

Lecture 3

Historically, international payment and international business first used precious metals such as gold and silver for international trade
Rapid development of payment platforms, the concept of "deposit" has gotten muddled
Payment platforms have expanded  rapidly over the past several years
The speed of transfers has become almost instantaneous
However, international transfers are more difficult if not nonexistent in most payment systems
However, the protections afforded depositors is not as strong as with financial institution deposit accounts
Payments platforms are not subject to the same regulatory oversight that banks and other financial institutions are

Lecture 4

Finance and Lending has many aspects and types
The first type worth noting is equity or debt
There are variations on forms of both debt and equity
There are also hybrid arrangements where an investment has attributes of both debt and equity
You will usually see this in startup companies with so-called "angel investors" who will extend a loan to the startup for a specific return but also get an equity portion and usually one or more seats on the board of directors
The equity portion can be quite significant, in some cases a majority interest in the company

Lecture 5

Most equity, especially for startups or younger is not traded on any public exchange, but rather in private transactions. 
It is therefore very important to know the investment laws of the jurisdiction where the startup is located and the jurisdiction where it is organized (which often times is different)
It is also very important to look at the investment laws where the investors are located. These laws will often apply as well if care is not taken by the company counsel to structure the investment carefully

Lecture 6
	
In lending arrangements, they may be bilateral or multilateral
This will apply to the lenders involved and not the borrowers
A bilateral arrangement is between one lender and on (or more borrowers
A multilateral arrangement is between two or more lenders and one (or more borrowers
There are several ways a multi-lateral arrangement can be structured
It is not uncommon to lenders to insist on the parent or significant affiliate of the borrower to be an obligor as well, or at least a guarantor
Facilities can be secured or unsecured

Lecture 7
Asset securitization
Other forms of structured finance

Some variations around the world
Overall trends
Questions /open discussion
